017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.cielab;
018
019import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
020import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
021import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
023import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
024import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.TrigTools;
025
026import java.util.Random;
027
028/**
029 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the CIE L*A*B* color space.
030 * This is the old standard (and for some things, gold standard) of color spaces, introduced in 1976 and never fully
031 * superseded by a newer color space. A reason there are still newer color spaces being introduced is in part that
032 * existing color spaces, such as CIELAB, don't have sufficient performance for a given task, and this is an especially
033 * fair criticism of CIELAB -- it's slow. But, if you calculate new colors infrequently and do the heaviest conversions
034 * in a shader, this might not be noticeably different from Oklab or IPT_HQ. This package emphasizes quality over speed,
035 * so some calculations that are approximated in Oklab and IPT_HQ are performed rigorously here.
036 * <br>
037 * The CIE L*A*B* color space has 3 channels, L, A, and B, each gamma-corrected (which is why an asterisk is added).
038 * L is lightness, A is a chroma axis that is (roughly) cyan-vs.-red, and B is a chroma axis that is (roughly)
039 * blue-vs.-yellow. This is the same in concept as Oklab, but Oklab is skewed somewhat so high B there is more orange
040 * than yellow; it's somewhat hard to accurately produce yellow in Oklab. This also has an alpha channel in each color,
041 * which acts like it does in every other color space package here (multiplicative alpha, higher is more opaque).
042 */
043public class ColorTools {
044    /**
045     * No need to instantiate.
046     */
047    private ColorTools(){
048    }
049    /**
050     * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
051     * (a chromatic component ranging from cyan to red), B (a chromatic component ranging from blue to yellow), and
052     * alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderCielab} as its shader, colors
053     * passed with {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as CIELAB. L
054     * should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very
055     * light colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
056     * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
057     * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
058     * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
059     * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
060     *
061     * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of CIELAB, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
062     * @param a     0f to 1f, A component of CIELAB, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
063     * @param b     0f to 1f, B component of CIELAB, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
064     * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
065     * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
066     */
067    public static float cielab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
068        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255.999f) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255.999f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
069                | ((int) (a * 255.999f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255.999f) & 0xFF));
070    }
071    /**
072     * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, L, A, B, and alpha, with each
073     * component clamped to the 0f to 1f range before being entered into the packed float color. This is only different
074     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)} in that it clamps each component. It still permits out-of-gamut
075     * colors to be stored, but as long as the rendering code (such as a shader or ColorfulBatch) does its own
076     * validation or correction of colors, then having out-of-gamut colors shouldn't be a problem.
077     *
078     * @see #cielab(float, float, float, float) This uses the same definitions for L, A, B, and alpha as cielab().
079     * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of CIELAB, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
080     * @param a     0f to 1f, A component of CIELAB, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
081     * @param b     0f to 1f, B component of CIELAB, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
082     * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
083     * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
084     */
085    public static float clamp(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
086        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((Math.min(Math.max((int) (alpha * 127.999f), 0), 127) << 25)
087                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (b * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16)
088                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (a * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8)
089                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (l * 255.999f), 0), 255))
090        );
091    }
092
093
094    /**
095     * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
096     * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
097     * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
098     * case it has in this class, it never is given negative inputs.
099     * <br>
100     * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
101     * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
102     * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
103     * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
104     * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
105     * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
106     * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
107     * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
108     * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
109     * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
110     * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
111     * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
112     * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
113     * <br>
114     * This is used when converting from RGB to CIELAB, as an intermediate step.
115     * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
116     * @return the cube root of x, approximated
117     */
118    private static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
119        int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
120        final float x0 = x;
121        ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
122        ix += (ix>>>4);
123        ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
124        x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
125        x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
126        x  = 0.33333334f*(1.9999999f * x + x0/(x*x));
127        return x;
128    }
129
130    /**
131     * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, using an exact gamma of 2.4 and accounting for the
132     * darkest colors with a different formula.
133     * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
134     * @return a linear version of component
135     */
136    private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
137        return component < 0.04045f ? component * (1f/12.92f) : (float)Math.pow((component + 0.055f) * (1f/1.055f), 2.4f);
138    }
139
140    /**
141     * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using an exact gamma of 2.4
142     * and accounting for the darkest colors with a different formula.
143     * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
144     * @return a non-linear version of component
145     */
146    private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
147        return component < 0.0031308f ? component * 12.92f : (float)Math.pow(component, 1f/2.4f) * 1.055f - 0.055f;
148    }
149
150    private static float forwardXYZ(final float t) {
151        return (t < 0.00885645f) ? 7.787037f * t + 0.139731f : cbrtPositive(t);
152    }
153
154    private static float reverseXYZ(final float t) {
155        return (t < 0.20689655f) ? 0.1284185f * (t - 0.139731f) : t * t * t;
156    }
157
158    /**
159     * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
160     * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
161     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
162     * @return an RGBA8888 int color
163     */
164    public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
165    {
166        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
167        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
168        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
169        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
170        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
171        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
172        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
173        final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
174        final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
175        final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
176        return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
177    }
178
179    /**
180     * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
181     * to a packed float in ABGR8888 format.
182     * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
183     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
184     * @return a packed float color as ABGR8888
185     */
186    public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
187    {
188        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
189        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
190        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
191        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
192        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
193        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
194        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
195        final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
196        final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
197        final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
198        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
199    }
200
201    /**
202     * Writes a CIELAB-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)})
203     * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
204     * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
205     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
206     * @return an RGBA8888 int color
207     */
208    public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
209    {
210        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
211        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
212//        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (1f / 127.5f);
213//        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (1f / 127.5f);
214        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
215        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
216        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
217        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
218        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
219        editing.r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
220        editing.g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
221        editing.b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
222        editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
223        return editing.clamp();
224    }
225
226    /**
227     * Writes a CIELAB-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)})
228     * into a CIELAB-format Color called {@code editing}. This is mostly useful if the rest of your application expects
229     * colors in CIELAB format, such as because you use {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderCielab} or {@link ColorfulBatch}.
230     * <br>
231     * Internally, this simply calls {@link Color#abgr8888ToColor(Color, float)} and returns the edited Color.
232     * @param editing a libGDX Color that will be filled in-place with the color {@code cielab}, unchanged from its color space
233     * @param cielab a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
234     * @return an RGBA8888 int color
235     */
236    public static Color toCIELABColor(Color editing, final float cielab){
237        Color.abgr8888ToColor(editing, cielab);
238        return editing;
239    }
240
241    /**
242     * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
243     * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
244     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
245     */
246    public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
247        final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
248        final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
249        final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
250
251        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r  + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
252        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r  + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
253        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r  + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
254
255        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
256                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
257                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)((x - y) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
258                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)((y - z) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
259                        | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
260    }
261
262    /**
263     * Takes a color encoded as an ABGR packed float and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
264     * @param packed a packed float in ABGR8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
265     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
266     */
267    public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
268        final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
269        final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
270        final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
271        final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
272
273        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
274        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
275        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
276
277        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
278                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
279                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
280                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
281                        | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
282    }
283
284    /**
285     * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
286     * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
287     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
288     */
289    public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
290        final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
291        final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
292        final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
293        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
294        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
295        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
296        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
297                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
298                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
299                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
300                        | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
301    }
302
303    /**
304     * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
305     * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
306     * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
307     * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
308     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
309     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
310     */
311    public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
312        r = forwardGamma(r);
313        g = forwardGamma(g);
314        b = forwardGamma(b);
315        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
316        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
317        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
318        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
319                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
320                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
321                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
322                        | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
323    }
324
325        /**
326         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
327         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
328         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
329         */
330        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
331        {
332        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
333        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
334        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
335        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
336        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
337        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
338        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
339        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
340        }
341
342        /**
343         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
344         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
345         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
346         */
347        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
348        {
349        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
350        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
351        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
352        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
353        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
354        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
355        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
356        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
357        }
358
359        /**
360         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
361         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
362         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
363         */
364        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
365        {
366        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
367        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
368        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
369        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
370        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
371        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
372        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
373        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
374        }
375
376        /**
377         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
378         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
379         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
380         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
381         */
382        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
383        {
384                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
385        }
386    /**
387     * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
388     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
389     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
390     */
391    public static float red(final float encoded)
392    {
393        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
394        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
395        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
396        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
397        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
398        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
399        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
400        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
401    }
402
403    /**
404     * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
405     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
406     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
407     */
408    public static float green(final float encoded)
409    {
410        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
411        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
412        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
413        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
414        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
415        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
416        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
417        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
418    }
419
420    /**
421     * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
422     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
423     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
424     */
425    public static float blue(final float encoded)
426    {
427        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
428        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
429        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
430        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
431        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
432        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
433        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
434        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
435    }
436
437    /**
438     * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
439     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
440     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
441     */
442    public static float alpha(final float encoded)
443    {
444        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
445    }
446
447
448    /**
449     * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given CIELAB color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
450     * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
451     * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
452     * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
453     * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
454     * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
455     * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
456     * 0 chroma, and the most colorful value (a shade of purple) should have 1.26365817 chroma.
457     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
458     * @return a float between 0.0f and 1.26365817 that represents how colorful the given value is
459     */
460    public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
461        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
462        final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
463        final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
464        return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
465    }
466    /**
467     * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (very approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
468     * combination, using CIELAB's versions of lightness and hue (not HSL). This is useful to know the bounds of
469     * {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater than 1.26365817f . Note that this version of chromaLimit() is
470     * much slower than Oklab's version, because this has to go to much greater lengths to become accurate.
471     * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
472     * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
473     * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 1.26365817f
474     */
475    public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness) {
476        final float h = hue - MathUtils.floor(hue);
477        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
478        final float A = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * (1.26365817f);
479        final float B = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * (1.26365817f);
480        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
481        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
482        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
483            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
484            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
485            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
486            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
487            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
488            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
489                break;
490            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
491            A2 = (A * progress);
492            B2 = (B * progress);
493        }
494        return (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2);
495    }
496    /**
497     * Gets the color with the same L as the CIELAB color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
498     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
499     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
500     * @param packed a packed float color in CIELAB format; does not need to be in-gamut
501     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
502     * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
503     */
504    public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
505        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
506        final float lightness = (decoded & 255) / 255f;
507        final float h = TrigTools.atan2Turns(((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f), ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f));
508        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
509        final float A = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * 1.26365817f * 0.2f;
510        final float B = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * 1.26365817f * 0.5f;
511        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
512        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
513        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
514            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
515            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
516            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
517            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
518            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
519            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
520                break;
521            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
522            A2 = (A * progress);
523            B2 = (B * progress);
524        }
525        return cielab(lightness, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
526    }
527    /**
528     * Gets the color with the same L as the CIELAB color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
529     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
530     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
531     * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
532     * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
533     * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
534     * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
535     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
536     * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
537     * for out-of-gamut colors.
538     */
539    public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
540        L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
541        A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
542        B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
543        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
544        final float h = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B - 0.5f, A - 0.5f);
545        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
546        final float A0 = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
547        final float B0 = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
548        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
549        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
550        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
551            final float x = reverseXYZ(L0 + A2);
552            final float z = reverseXYZ(L0 - B2);
553            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
554            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
555            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
556            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
557                break;
558            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
559            A2 = (A0 * progress);
560            B2 = (B0 * progress);
561        }
562        return cielab(L, A2, B2, alpha);
563    }
564
565    /**
566     * Gets the hue of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands hue rather than how HSL does.
567     * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
568     * and 1 (exclusive).
569     *
570     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
571     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the CIELAB color space
572     */
573    public static float cielabHue(final float packed) {
574        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
575        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
576        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
577        return TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
578    }
579
580    /**
581     * Gets the saturation of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands saturation rather than how HSL
582     * does. Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue
583     * and lightness, and is between 0 and 1. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive).
584     *
585     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
586     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the CIELAB color space
587     */
588    public static float cielabSaturation(final float packed) {
589        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
590        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(((decoded & 0xff) / 255f) + 0.16f);
591        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
592        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
593        final float h = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
594        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
595        final float A0 = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
596        final float B0 = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
597        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
598        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
599        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
600            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
601            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
602            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
603            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
604            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
605            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
606                break;
607            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
608            A2 = (A0 * progress);
609            B2 = (B0 * progress);
610        }
611        final float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2);
612        return (float) Math.sqrt(A * A + B * B) / dist;
613    }
614    /**
615     * Gets the lightness of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
616     * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
617     * and 1 (inclusive).
618     * <br>
619     * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
620     *
621     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
622     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the CIELAB color space
623     */
624    public static float cielabLightness(final float packed){
625        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
626    }
627
628    /**
629     * A different way to specify a CIELAB color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
630     * but calculating them directly in the CIELAB color space. This is more efficient than
631     * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}. You may prefer using
632     * {@link #cielabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation
633     * here (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
634     * <br>
635     * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
636     * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
637     * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
638     * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
639     * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #cielabHue(float)}, {@link #cielabSaturation(float)},
640     * and {@link #cielabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
641     * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too). This method is likely to be significantly slower than
642     * {@link #cielabByHCL(float, float, float, float)} because this needs to calculate the gamut.
643     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
644     * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
645     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
646     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
647     * @return a packed CIELAB float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
648     */
649    public static float cielabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
650        lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
651        saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
652        hue -= MathUtils.floor(hue);
653        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
654        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
655        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
656        final float cos = TrigTools.cosTurns(hue);
657        final float sin = TrigTools.sinTurns(hue);
658        final float A0 = cos * 1.26365817f * 0.2f;
659        final float B0 = sin * 1.26365817f * 0.5f;
660        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
661        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
662        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
663            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
664            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
665            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
666            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
667            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
668            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
669                break;
670            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
671            A2 = (A0 * progress);
672            B2 = (B0 * progress);
673        }
674        final float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2) * saturation;
675        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
676                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
677                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (sin * dist + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16 |
678                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (cos * dist + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8 |
679                        (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
680    }
681
682    /**
683     * A different way to specify a CIELAB color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
684     * color but calculating them directly in the CIELAB color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
685     * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
686     * (saturation is what {@link #cielabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different
687     * value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the
688     * method {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent
689     * to {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
690     * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
691     * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
692     * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #cielabHue(float)},
693     * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #cielabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
694     * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too). This method should be significantly faster
695     * than {@link #cielabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} because it doesn't need to calculate the gamut.
696     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
697     * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
698     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
699     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
700     * @return a packed CIELAB float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
701     */
702    public static float cielabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
703        lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
704        chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f) * 127.5f;
705        hue -= MathUtils.floor(hue);
706        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
707        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
708                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
709                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) /* * 2f */ * chroma + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16 |
710                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) /* * 5f */ * chroma + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8 |
711                        (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
712    }
713
714    /**
715     * Gets a color as a CIELAB packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
716     * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
717     * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
718     * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
719     * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
720     * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
721     * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
722     * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
723     *
724     * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
725     * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
726     * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
727     * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
728     * @return a CIELAB float encoding a color with the given properties
729     */
730    public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
731        if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
732            return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
733        } else {
734            return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
735        }
736    }
737
738    /**
739     * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
740     * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details.
741     *
742     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
743     * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
744     */
745    public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
746        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
747        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
748        if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
749        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
750        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
751        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
752        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
753        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
754        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
755        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
756        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
757        float X, Y, W;
758        if(g < b) {
759            X = b;
760            Y = g;
761        }
762        else {
763            X = g;
764            Y = b;
765        }
766        if(r < X) {
767            W = r;
768        }
769        else {
770            W = X;
771            X = r;
772        }
773        return X - Math.min(W, Y);
774    }
775
776    /**
777     * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for CIELAB. This
778     * ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f (white).
779     *
780     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
781     * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
782     */
783    public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
784        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
785        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
786        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
787        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
788        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
789        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
790        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
791        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
792        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
793        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
794        float X, Y, W;
795        if(g < b) {
796            X = b;
797            Y = g;
798        }
799        else {
800            X = g;
801            Y = b;
802        }
803        if(r < X) {
804            W = r;
805        }
806        else {
807            W = X;
808            X = r;
809        }
810        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
811        return X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
812    }
813
814    /**
815     * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
816     * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
817     *
818     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
819     * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
820     * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
821     */
822    public static float hue(final float encoded) {
823        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
824        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
825        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
826        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
827        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
828        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
829        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
830        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
831        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
832        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
833        float X, Y, Z, W;
834        if(g < b) {
835            X = b;
836            Y = g;
837            Z = -1f;
838            W = 2f / 3f;
839        }
840        else {
841            X = g;
842            Y = b;
843            Z = 0f;
844            W = -1f / 3f;
845        }
846        if(r < X) {
847            Z = W;
848            W = r;
849        }
850        else {
851            W = X;
852            X = r;
853        }
854        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
855        return Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
856    }
857    /**
858     * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
859     * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not CIELAB! Takes
860     * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
861     * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
862     * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different than the
863     * result of {@code basis} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
864     * This won't allocate any objects.
865     * <br>
866     * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
867     * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
868     * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
869     * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
870     * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
871     *
872     * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
873     * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
874     * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
875     * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
876     * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
877     * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
878     */
879    public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
880        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
881        final float li = Math.min(Math.max(light + (decoded & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
882        opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) * (1f / 127f), 0f), 1f);
883        if (li <= 0.001f)
884            return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
885        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(li + 0.16f);
886        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
887        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
888        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
889        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
890        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
891        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
892        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
893        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
894        float X, Y, Z, W;
895        if(g < b) {
896            X = b;
897            Y = g;
898            Z = -1f;
899            W = 2f / 3f;
900        }
901        else {
902            X = g;
903            Y = b;
904            Z = 0f;
905            W = -1f / 3f;
906        }
907        if(r < X) {
908            Z = W;
909            W = r;
910        }
911        else {
912            W = X;
913            X = r;
914        }
915        final float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
916        final float lum = X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
917        hue += Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
918        saturation += (X - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
919        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
920    }
921
922
923    /**
924     * Given a packed float CIELAB color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
925     * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
926     * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
927     * resulting color so it contains in-range L, A, B, and alpha values, but it doesn't guarantee it stays in-gamut.
928     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
929     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
930     * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
931     * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
932     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
933     * @return a packed float CIELAB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
934     */
935    public static float editCIELAB(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
936        return editCIELAB(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
937    }
938    /**
939     * Given a packed float CIELAB color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel
940     * by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This
941     * means the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is
942     * clamped to the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float
943     * can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a
944     * value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5
945     * range, so if you multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color,
946     * and if you multiply by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This
947     * clamps the resulting color so it contains in-range L, A, B, and alpha values, but it doesn't guarantee it stays
948     * in-gamut.
949     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
950     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
951     * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
952     * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
953     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
954     * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
955     * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
956     * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
957     * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
958     * @return a packed float CIELAB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
959     */
960    public static float editCIELAB(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
961                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
962        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
963        float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
964        float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f)  * (0.2f / 127.5f);
965        float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
966        float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
967
968        L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
969        A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
970        B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
971        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
972        return clamp(L, A, B, alpha);
973    }
974
975    /**
976     * The "L" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
977     * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
978     *
979     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
980     * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
981     */
982    public static float channelL(final float encoded)
983    {
984        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
985    }
986
987    /**
988     * The "A" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
989     * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
990     * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
991     * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
992     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
993     * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
994     */
995    public static float channelA(final float encoded)
996    {
997        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
998    }
999
1000    /**
1001     * The "B" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
1002     * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
1003     * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
1004     * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
1005     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
1006     * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1007     */
1008    public static float channelB(final float encoded)
1009    {
1010        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
1011    }
1012
1013    /**
1014     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1015     * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
1016     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1017     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1018     * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
1019     * chroma of start as-is.
1020     * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
1021     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1022     * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
1023     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
1024     */
1025    public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
1026        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
1027        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
1028    }
1029
1030    /**
1031     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1032     * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
1033     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1034     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1035     * towards black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
1036     * chroma of start as-is.
1037     * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
1038     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1039     * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
1040     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
1041     */
1042    public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
1043        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
1044        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
1045    }
1046
1047    /**
1048     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
1049     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
1050     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1051     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1052     * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
1053     * alpha and L of start as-is.
1054     * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
1055     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1056     * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
1057     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
1058     */
1059    public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
1060        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1061        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
1062    }
1063
1064    /**
1065     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
1066     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
1067     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1068     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1069     * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
1070     * L of start as-is.
1071     * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
1072     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1073     * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
1074     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
1075     */
1076    public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
1077        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1078        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
1079    }
1080
1081    /**
1082     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
1083     * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed
1084     * color, as from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
1085     * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
1086     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
1087     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
1088     * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
1089     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1090     * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
1091     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
1092     */
1093    public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
1094        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1095        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
1096    }
1097
1098    /**
1099     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
1100     * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed
1101     * color, as from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
1102     * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
1103     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more artificial color. Unlike
1104     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
1105     * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
1106     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1107     * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
1108     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
1109     */
1110    public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
1111        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1112        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
1113    }
1114
1115    /**
1116     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
1117     * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1118     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1119     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1120     * towards transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
1121     * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
1122     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1123     * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
1124     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
1125     */
1126    public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
1127        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1128        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1129    }
1130
1131    /**
1132     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
1133     * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1134     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1135     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1136     * lerp towards transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
1137     * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
1138     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1139     * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
1140     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
1141     */
1142    public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
1143        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1144        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1145    }
1146
1147    /**
1148     * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
1149     * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
1150     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone.
1151     * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
1152     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1153     * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
1154     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
1155     */
1156    public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
1157        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
1158        return cielab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
1159                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
1160                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
1161                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
1162    }
1163
1164    /**
1165     * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
1166     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
1167     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. This prevents high values for change
1168     * from pushing A or B out of the valid range by using {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)}; this doesn't
1169     * actually keep the color in-gamut, but usually rendering code can handle out-of-gamut colors in some way.
1170     * Alpha. The alpha never changes. It never changes L either.
1171     * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
1172     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1173     * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
1174     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
1175     */
1176    public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
1177        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
1178        return clamp((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
1179                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
1180                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
1181                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
1182    }
1183
1184    /**
1185     * Given a packed float CIELAB color {@code mainColor} and another CIELAB color that it should be made to contrast with,
1186     * gets a packed float CIELAB color with roughly inverted lightness but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
1187     * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
1188     * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
1189     * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
1190     * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the lightness unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
1191     * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
1192     * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
1193     * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
1194     * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
1195     * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
1196     * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
1197     * @return a different CIELAB packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
1198     */
1199    public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1200    {
1201        final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
1202                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
1203                L = (bits & 0xff),
1204                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1205                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
1206                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
1207                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1208                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
1209        if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
1210            return mainColor;
1211        return cielab(cL < 128 ? L * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.5f : 0.5f - L * (0.45f / 255f), A / 255f, B / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
1212    }
1213
1214    /**
1215     * Given a packed float CIELAB color {@code mainColor} and another CIELAB color that it should be made to contrast
1216     * with, gets a packed float CIELAB color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
1217     * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
1218     * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
1219     * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
1220     * <br>
1221     * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
1222     * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
1223     * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
1224     * @param mainColor a packed CIELAB float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
1225     * @param contrastingColor a packed CIELAB float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
1226     * @return a different packed CIELAB float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
1227     */
1228    public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1229    {
1230        final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
1231        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1232    }
1233
1234    /**
1235     * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
1236     * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1237     * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1238     * @param mainColor a packed CIELAB float color
