1239     * @return a different packed CIELAB float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
1240     */
1241    public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1242        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1243        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1244    }
1245
1246    /**
1247     * Makes the additive CIELAB color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1248     * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1249     * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1250     * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
1251     * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1252     * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1253     * @return a CIELAB float color between gray and {@code color}
1254     */
1255    public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1256        final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1257                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80,
1258                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1259        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
1260                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1261                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1262                | (eAlpha << 24));
1263    }
1264
1265    /**
1266     * Returns true if the given packed float color, as CIELAB, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1267     * @param packed a packed float color as CIELAB
1268     * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1269     */
1270    public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1271    {
1272        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1273        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1274        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1275        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1276        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1277        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1278        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1279        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1280        if(r <= -0x1p-8f || r >= 0x1.01p0f) return false;
1281        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1282        if(g <= -0x1p-8f || g >= 0x1.01p0f) return false;
1283        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1284        return (b > -0x1p-8f && b < 0x1.01p0f);
1285
1286//        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1287//        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1288//        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1289//        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1290//        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1291//        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1292//        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1293//        boolean ret = true;
1294//        final float r = +3.2406f * x + -1.5372f * y + -0.4986f * z;
1295////        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1296//        if(r <= -0x1p-8f || r >= 0x1.01p0f) ret = false;
1297////        final float g = -0.9689f * x + +1.8758f * y + +0.0415f * z;
1298//        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1299//        if(g <= -0x1p-8f || g >= 0x1.01p0f) ret = false;
1300////        final float b = +0.0557f * x + -0.2040f * y + +1.0570f * z;
1301//        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1302//        ret &= (b > -0x1p-8f && b < 0x1.01p0f);
1303//        if(!ret) System.out.printf("L %f, A %f, B %f, x %f, y %f, z %f, r %f, g %f, b %f\n", L, A, B,  x, y, z,  r, g, b);
1304//        return ret;
1305
1306    }
1307
1308    /**
1309     * Returns true if the given CIELAB values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1310     * @param L lightness, as a float from 0 to 1
1311     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma, as a float from 0 to 1
1312     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma, as a float from 0 to 1
1313     * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1314     */
1315    public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1316    {
1317        L = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
1318        A = (A - 0.5f) * (0.4f);
1319        B = (B - 0.5f);
1320        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1321        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1322        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1323        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1324        if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
1325        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1326        if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
1327        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1328        return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
1329    }
1330
1331    /**
1332     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if
1333     * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the L of the color, only bringing A and B
1334     * closer to grayscale. Note that this version of limitToGamut() is much slower than Oklab's version, because Oklab
1335     * stores its entire gamut as a large constant, while this has to calculate it.
1336     * @param packed a packed float color in CIELAB format; often this color is not in-gamut
1337     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1338     * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1339     */
1340    public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1341        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1342        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1343        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1344        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1345        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1346        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
1347        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1348            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
1349            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
1350            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
1351            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
1352            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
1353            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1354                break;
1355            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
1356            A2 = (A * progress);
1357            B2 = (B * progress);
1358        }
1359        return cielab(L, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1360    }
1361
1362    /**
1363     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
1364     * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the L of the color, only bringing A and B
1365     * closer to grayscale. This always produces an opaque color.
1366     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1367     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1368     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1369     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1370     * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1371     */
1372    public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1373        return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1374    }
1375    /**
1376     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
1377     * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Note that this version of limitToGamut() is much slower
1378     * than Oklab's version, because Oklab stores its entire gamut as a large constant, while this has to calculate it.
1379     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1380     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1381     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1382     * @param alpha opacity; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1383     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1384     * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1385     */
1386    public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1387
1388        L = (1f/1.16f)*(Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f) + 0.16f);
1389        A = (Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f) * 0.4f;
1390        B = (Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f);
1391        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1392
1393        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1394        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
1395        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1396            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
1397            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
1398            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
1399            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
1400            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
1401            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1402                break;
1403            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
1404            A2 = (A * progress);
1405            B2 = (B * progress);
1406        }
1407        return cielab(L, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1408    }
1409
1410    /**
1411     * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1412     * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1413     * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1414     * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1415     * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
1416     * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1417     * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
1418     * but only internally for measuring distance).
1419     * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
1420     * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1421     * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1422     * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1423     */
1424    public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1425        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1426        final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1427        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1428        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1429        final float limit = variance * variance;
1430        float dist, x, y, z;
1431        for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1432            x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1433            y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1434            z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1435            seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1436            dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1437            if(dist <= limit)
1438                return clamp(x + L, (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1439        }
1440        return color;
1441    }
1442
1443    /**
1444     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
1445     * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1446     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1447     */
1448    public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1449        float L = random.nextFloat();
1450        float A = random.nextFloat();
1451        float B = random.nextFloat();
1452        while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1453            L = random.nextFloat();
1454            A = random.nextFloat();
1455            B = random.nextFloat();
1456        }
1457        return cielab(L, A, B, 1f);
1458    }
1459
1460}
